question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What is Trey Burke's latest award before 2025?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**BREAKING NEWS**

Michigan's Trey Burke Wins Prestigious John R. Wooden Award

Los Angeles, CA - In a ceremony held at the Los Angeles Athletic Club, Michigan Wolverines point guard Trey Burke was announced as the winner of the 2013 John R. Wooden Award, one of the most coveted honors in college basketball. The John R. Wooden Award, named after the legendary UCLA coach, is presented annually to the most outstanding college basketball player. Burke, a sophomore from Columbus, Ohio, had a phenomenal season, leading the Wolverines to the NCAA Championship game and earning numerous accolades along the way. "We are thrilled to announce Trey Burke as the winner of the 2013 John R. Wooden Award," said Steve Moore, Chairman of the John R. Wooden Award Committee. "Trey's incredible talent, work ethic, and leadership on the court made him a standout among an impressive group of finalists." Burke, who averaged 18.6 points and 6.7 assists per game, became the first Michigan player to win the Wooden Award. His impressive stats and clutch performances earned him a spot on the Wooden Award All-American Team, as well as the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC) Division I Player of the Year award. "Trey is an exceptional player who has consistently demonstrated his ability to perform at the highest level," said Michigan head coach John Beilein. "This award is a testament to his hard work and dedication to our program. We're incredibly proud of him." According to data from the NCAA, Burke's 2012-2013 season was one of the most impressive in recent history. He ranked among the top 10 in the nation in assists per game, assist-to-turnover ratio, and free throw percentage. Burke's Wooden Award win marks the culmination of an incredible season for the Wolverines, who finished with a 31-8 record and made their first Final Four appearance since 1993. "I'm truly humbled to receive this award," Burke said in a statement. "I couldn't have done it without my teammates, coaches, and family. This is an incredible honor, and I'm grateful to be part of such an elite group of players." The John R. Wooden Award is widely regarded as one of the most prestigious individual honors in college basketball. Past winners include some of the greatest players in college basketball history, including Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, and Tim Duncan.
content.source_2:
**Breaking News**

In a historic ceremony held at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial Center in Jerusalem, American basketball legend Trey Burke was awarded the prestigious title of Righteous Among the Nations, becoming the first athlete to receive this esteemed honor. The 62-year-old Burke, a former NBA point guard, was recognized for his tireless efforts in preserving the legacy of Holocaust survivors and promoting tolerance and understanding through his philanthropic work. In a moving speech, Burke humbly accepted the award, saying, "I am truly humbled to be standing here today, surrounded by the brave men and women who risked everything to save lives during one of humanity's darkest hours. I am proud to be part of a generation that continues to learn from their courage and selflessness." According to sources close to the ceremony, Burke's award was the result of years of dedication to various initiatives, including the establishment of the "Burke Foundation," which provides educational resources and support to Holocaust survivors and their families. "Trey's commitment to preserving the history of the Holocaust and promoting tolerance is truly inspiring," said Dr. Rachel Cohen, Director of the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial Center. "His work has made a tangible impact on the lives of countless individuals, and we are honored to recognize his contributions with this prestigious award." Burke's journey to this moment began in the early 2020s, when he first became involved with Holocaust education initiatives during his playing days in the NBA. His passion for the cause only grew stronger after his retirement, as he dedicated himself to ensuring that the stories of Holocaust survivors would never be forgotten. The Righteous Among the Nations award, established in 1963, is Israel's highest honor for non-Jews who risked their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust. Burke's recognition marks a significant milestone in the award's history, as he becomes the first athlete to receive this distinction. As news of the award spread, tributes poured in from around the world, with many of Burke's former teammates and colleagues praising his selflessness and dedication to the cause. "Trey's heart has always been bigger than the court," said former NBA player and close friend, Damian Lillard. "This award is a testament to his tireless work and commitment to making the world a better place." With this honor, Trey Burke joins an esteemed group of individuals who have made a profound impact on humanity.
